importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei made a claim in March about AI writing 90% of code within three to six months.
Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg made a prediction in April about AI contributing to half of development in a project within the next year.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article discusses ongoing developments and debates about AI in software engineering as of 2025, with recent claims and studies from that year.

keyTakeAways: Tech CEOs such as Dario Amodei, Mark Zuckerberg, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft are making bold claims about AI writing a large portion of code, suggesting a shift toward AI-driven software development.
Despite the enthusiasm, many software engineers, including Colton Voege and Simon Willison, express skepticism, noting that AI-generated code often requires significant human review and correction.
AI tools are most effective in generating quick prototypes or short-lived tools, where accuracy is less critical, but they often fail in complex or long-term development tasks.
Studies show mixed results: a METR study found experienced engineers took 19% longer with AI, while a Danish survey reported only a 6.5% time saving, considered modest.
The term 'workslop' has been coined to describe instances where AI is used inappropriately or without justification, leading to messy, unworkable code and increased team workload.
AI usage is being mandated or encouraged by companies like Amazon and Meta, sometimes leading to pressure on engineers to adopt AI even when it’s not beneficial.
Concerns exist about AI replacing junior software engineers, reducing long-term talent supply and human oversight.
Environmental concerns are raised regarding the massive energy and data consumption required by large language models.
Experts like Boris Cherny and Simon Willison emphasize that AI is not autonomous — every line of code should still be reviewed by a human engineer.

namedEntities.name: Dario Amodei
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dario Amodei made a bold prediction in March 2025 that AI would write 90% of code within three to six months, setting a high bar for AI's role in software development.

namedEntities.name: Mark Zuckerberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mark Zuckerberg predicted in April 2025 that AI would contribute to about half of software development in one project within the next year, indicating a major shift in development workflows.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon executives and engineers have promoted AI coding tools, with management encouraging AI use even when unnecessary, leading to 'workslop' issues and inefficiencies.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google engineers have expressed skepticism about AI trustworthiness, with a survey showing only half of respondents somewhat trust AI-generated code, highlighting concerns about reliability and overuse.

namedEntities.name: Microsoft
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Microsoft is part of the broader tech ecosystem promoting AI coding, reflecting industry-wide ambition to automate software development with AI tools.

namedEntities.name: Anthropic
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Anthropic developed Claude Code, which claims to generate most code and use AI agents to test and rewrite code, though human review is required for all code.

namedEntities.name: Claude Code
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Claude Code is highlighted as a tool that can auto-generate and test code via agents, but engineers report it can go into 'death spirals' and still requires human oversight.

namedEntities.name: OpenAI
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Simon Willison previewed OpenAI's latest model and acknowledged AI may write high percentages of code, but emphasized human involvement in problem-solving and system design.

namedEntities.name: Colton Voege
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Voege is a software engineer who tried AI tools and found limited productivity gains, and later left his job, reflecting broader engineer skepticism about AI's real-world impact.

namedEntities.name: Boris Cherny
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head of Anthropic's Claude Code unit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boris Cherny stated that every line of code must be reviewed by a human and described AI agents as functioning like a 'thought partner,' not a full replacement for engineers.

namedEntities.name: Simon Willison
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Independent AI researcher and open-source developer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Willison argues that AI can boost productivity for experienced programmers on specific tasks, but cannot perform higher-level problem-solving, and that AI adoption must be strategic and expert-driven.

namedEntities.name: Thomas Ptacek
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ptacek noted that AI helps with repetitive coding tasks, allowing faster iteration and pattern recognition, especially for familiar codebases.

namedEntities.name: Anders Humlum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Co-author of a Danish study on AI usage
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Humlum reported that software engineers in Denmark saved only 6.5% of time with AI, which he described as modest, highlighting limited real-world productivity gains.

namedEntities.name: METR
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: METR conducted a study showing experienced open-source engineers took 19% longer when using LLMs, contradicting expectations and challenging AI's efficiency claims.

namedEntities.name: Y Combinator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Y Combinator previously supported diverse technologies but now focuses solely on AI, reflecting a broader industry shift toward AI-driven innovation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Tech CEOs from major companies like Anthropic, Meta, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft are promoting AI's ability to write vast portions of software code, with claims ranging from 90% to 50% automation. However, many software engineers, including Colton Voege and Simon Willison, express skepticism, noting that AI-generated code often requires extensive human review and correction, and that AI tools frequently fail in complex tasks or produce unworkable 'messy blobs' of code. Studies show mixed results — one found engineers took 19% longer with AI, while another reported only a 6.5% time saving. Experts emphasize that AI is best used for rapid prototyping or repetitive tasks, not for solving high-level engineering problems. Concerns are growing about job displacement for junior engineers, inappropriate use (referred to as 'workslop'), environmental costs, and the lack of human oversight. Despite industry enthusiasm, the reality remains that human engineers remain essential in reviewing, validating, and ultimately shaping software development.
title: Tech CEOs Say the Era of 'Code by AI' Is Here, But Engineers Remain Skeptical
